instructors: Andre Moura Da Costa E Sousa

ratings.comment: Never posted materials outside of class, and in lecture, the slides barely had words to write down important concepts. This is problematic when we are learning about complex parts of the brain and a bunch of scientific jargon. When concepts came up on the test, it would be more helpful to have some reference materials (he has weekly quizzes).

Be ready to read a lot! This course is very lecture and textbook-heavy. That said, Professor Postle is easy to talk to and really helpful during office hours—definitely go if you're feeling lost (which I often was, haha). Would I retake this specific class? Probably not. But I would take another class with him, just not 505.

Dr. Postle is one of my favorite professors I've had at UW-Madison. I took PSYCH414&505, and while the material is challenging, he cares and provides many opportunities for students to gain a real understanding of the content. His exams are VERY difficult, but if you go to lecture, read the textbook, and study the assigned questions you'll be fine.

super interesting content and the lectures were entertaining and captivating. Prof Postle is hilarious and engaging, but the class is graded on 3 exams and a series of completion based quizzes. Tough class, but highly recommend

This class was difficult for me to follow along with. I attended almost every single lecture but they never seemed to help when it came to exam content. The class is solely test graded and I never knew exactly what to expect on the exams. Not being curved, the class was very difficult. Professor Postle was very nice but needed clearer lectures.

Super interesting class but there is definitely a lot of content to memorize and be able to understand complicated concepts. He has a very interesting teaching style that not for everyone. He will randomly reference students or make dad-jokes which was endearing but sometimes awkward. Textbook and readings not necessary but help a lot.

He records and shares all lectures and shares slides only when something has a lot of information that would take too long to write in real time. It's easy to tell that he cares about the information he's lecturing on, but he can get frustrated when students don't pick up the less difficult content as quickly. Grades were limited to quizzes & exams

You definitely have to put in effort when it comes to doing the quizzes and readings. The lectures are interesting, and postle (although intimidating) has a dad-like sense of humor.  The class is relatively difficult, but if you are willing to put in the work, you can do well. Also tests are about 35-45 questions all MC!
Lectures are interesting and he's funny but the tests can be hard if you don't understand what he's asking for. Kind of difficult for a psych class but overall I enjoyed it.

Definitely a tough course as UW psychology courses go in terms of the complexity of content, and he'd often move through content on the lectures very quickly which was tough. To succeed in the course, All of the content on the exams is in lectures and quizzes(homework), but because of the complexity and density, readings are extremely helpful.

Postle is overall a very good professor. His material is interesting and he does not require you to purchase a textbook, which is a perk. His lectures were interesting and straightforward. Minimal studying is needed, as long as you do the pre-lecture readings.

He's probably one of the worst professors I've taken at UW. His lectures are disorganized and he continuously takes moments throughout the lecture to stare at his computer. He's pretty nice and will work with you if you're struggling in the class but his "help" is not helpful because his exams are very difficult and wordy. Do NOT take this class.

He is a fine person, but I just don't find his lectures all that intriguing. Also, the wording of the tests doesn't test your knowledge of the actual material so much as it tests your ability to understand what he's saying. Uses very academic jargon which can be difficult to digest, and often there isn't anything explaining the term online.
The most unorganized and unprepared professor I've had. Just rambles/goes on tangents during lecture and comes off as rude in an attempt to be funny.
awful
Not much to say, awesome professor.

Prof. Postle is a nice guy in general but I am so glad I am done with his class. He goes through his material extremely quickly. As everyone else has mentioned, the exams are difficult, and it doesn't help that the three exams make up 75% of your grade. I would study my notes for hours and still get failing grades. Good luck. Go to lecture and work

Professor Postle really does care about his students but the content of the class and the way he taught is SO confusing. It wasn't even that the content was hard it was the way he formatted lectures- it almost seemed like he wanted to make it confusing. DO NOT TAKE !

I usually really enjoy anything psych related, but this was a class I dreaded going to every day. I really felt as though I understood the material, but I still didn't do well on exams even after studying a TON. Brad didn't know how to help students with studying tips and understanding material. Going to office hours seemed like a waste of time.

The exams are really hard to study for. The questions are more based on your ability to understand what he is asking rather than understanding content. The textbook is helpful but you basically need to know every single thing said in lecture AND in the textbook notes. The quizzes are helpful and it is kind of him to provide those as a grade boost.

Quite honestly the most frustrating class I have ever taken. His lectures make virtually no sense and his tests are based pretty much completely on them. He's very understanding and seems like a great guy, but the class itself was not worth it Would never take again.

Professor Postle's PSYCH 414 is full of deep and engaging materials that will help you truly appreciate the beauty of this field. The class can be difficult at times but is definitely worth the effort. He is willing to help students outside the class but may seem a bit arrogant and oddly humorous. Tests are fair (based closely on lecture).

Professor Postle is by far the worst professor I've had at this university. There's virtually no practice you get with the material; he always explains content in a roundabout way, and the material is very esoteric. There's only 3 exams, no curve, with weirdly worded questions & he grades very unfairly. Avoid this class at all costs.

Lectures are long and sometimes dry, but if you take good notes and pay attention, you likely will do fine with minimal study time. Graded on three non-cumulative MC exams and weekly short quiz completion. Readings are minimally relevant. He hosts review sessions and posts his lectures online. His personality takes a little getting used to.

Brad's class was, without contest, the worst educational experience of my life. He is disorganized, rude and his tests are graded in a completely arbitrary way. Most importantly, Brad is boarderline abusive to his students. I've heard of multiple people who had serious anxiety problems after dealing with him. DO NOT TAKE HIS CLASS.

The hardest class ever. He gives you insufficient slides (that weren't accessible) for extremely hard concepts and barely anytime to take notes. When he goes on tangents, he rarely explicitly states the topic/concept so you never know what he's talking about. Textbook was practically irrelevant (he wrote it). Very pompous. Tests were unfair. :(

Prof Postle has the most incoherent lecture style I have experienced at this university. Refuses to post lecture slides but lectures quickly and jumps from topic to topic. Many resorted to taking pictures of his slides. The readings rarely align with the lectures. So never miss lecture or space out for two seconds :D Exams are written pretentiously

Lectures weren't posted online so attendance was mandatory. Brad would go on tangents about topics, so the clear definition of a concept was never given and you weren't sure of what you needed to know on the exam. Exams were worded weirdly which made you question every possible answer. Textbook reading was difficult to understand when from his tb.

He makes you read from the textbook that he wrote, which is too advanced for this class so it makes it hard to comprehend what you're reading. during lecture, nothing is ever clearly defined, and he can be confusing. the wording of the tests can also be confusing and difficult even if youre well prepared.

The class overall was pretty interesting, but way more difficult than it needed to be. He never gave a clear definition for anything, he always used a really roundabout way of describing things. The first exam was terrible, he gives a study guide but you have to think about the answers much deeper than what he asks to get any use. Reading helps.

Brad is one of the funniest professors I have had & uses good examples to illustrate lectures. You will have to take very good notes & go to office hours to understand the concepts central to the exams, which are often not mentioned in the textbook. Grading is strict & exams are difficult, but cog. psych is so interesting it is worth the effort.

Brad does a great job of explaining concepts with definitions, experiments, and real examples, and he connects course concepts together. Lectures are enjoyable and thought-provoking. Attendance is mandatory because notes or videos are not posted online, but definitely worth going to. Online quizzes are very helpful and only graded by doing them.

Brad is a great teacher and funny. His lectures can be hard to follow because he dosnt post slides and just talks all lecture without slides. I've never done bad in a class but I did really bad in his class. His exams are super wordy and tough, I talked to other people in the class who thought the same. No matter how hard you study you won't good.

Tests are an unreasonable estimation of lecture and textbook understanding, and questions are phrased ineffectively. There is a lot of textbook reading (hundreds of pages) and lecture material is just as important. Brad's constant attempts at distasteful humor distracts from the interesting material, and his personal anecdotes get pretty weird.

Brad is hilarious and is a very intelligent guy. The class itself is a little dry but he tries to make it more engaging. He requires reading and quizzes that help your grade. The only downside is the exams and if you miss lecture. They are pretty tricky and everything he says in lecture could be on the exams, so take good notes and do the readings.

The honors seminar for Cognitive Psych is comprised of reading something each week, writing a question about it, and then listening to him talk in a small lecture room for 75 minutes once a week. Easy 1-credit A but difficult to stay awake through on a Thursday afternoon.

If you have a neuro background, the class isn't too bad, but no matter how much you study (whether you're a Neuro major or a Psych major or anything), it's easy to get tripped up on his confusing exam questions. The fact that he won't usually put his slides online means you have to pay VERY close attention during class.

The professor and TA mean well, but I recommend not taking it if you do not have to. The three tests are incredibly hard and found no matter what I did I always had the same results. This class is interesting, but the motivation drained out of me as the semester went on. Definitely a class you do not feel accomplished towards the end.

I was disappointed in this class, because I was looking forward to it being a really interesting. Instead I was really turned off by his personality, and that made it hard for me to muster the motivation to concentrate. That, and the fact that the lectures were hard to follow in the first place.

This is one of those professors who makes test questions impossible to understand unless you're a genius. You really have to know everything to do well on tests and it's not one of the classes  where you can memorize everything. It's a super boring class if you ask me and I would not recommend it to anyone. And I'm a psych major.
All i can say is that he loves to use long words, even when it isint necessary. Not very clear on anything

LOVED this class! He is very interesting to listen to in lecture and very helpful outside of class. If you read and take decent notes, you will get a good grade. He holds a review session DURING class before each exam that basically outlines what you need to know.

He is a great professor. I highly recommend him. If you prepare well for the exams and attend lecture, you will do fine on the exams. He really cares about his students unlike a lot of professors and is willing to go the extra mile for you to be successful in his  class. Don't freak out at first about the idea of online labs, they are very easy and
Really hard class.  Brad is dry but does crack the occasional pretty funny joke, but usually tries too hard to make jokes.
hardest class ever. he is so full of himself and the tests are worded terribly. very frusterating, i wouldnt take this class
exams unfair.  lecture sometimes unclear
SO hard, terrible exams
Brad rocks my box
Good lecturer, although his tests are very difficult to understand.
